description: From Old French contremander, from Medieval Latin contramandō, from contra + mandō (“I order; I command”).

entries.meaning: An order to the contrary of a previous one.

verbs.description: countermand (third-person singular simple present countermands, present participle countermanding, simple past and past participle countermanded) (transitive)

entries.meaning: To revoke (a former command); to cancel or rescind by giving an order contrary to one previously given.
examples: to countermand an order for goods

entries.meaning: To recall a person or unit with such an order.
To cancel an order for (some specified goods).
examples: Three of the maids of honour ſent to countermand their birth-day cloaths; two of them burnt all their collections of novels and romances, and ſent to a bookſeller’s in Pall-mall to buy each of them a bible, and Taylor’s holy living and dying.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) To counteract, to act against, to frustrate.
(obsolete) To prohibit (a course of action or behavior).
(obsolete) To oppose or revoke the command of (someone).
examples: For us to alter anything, is to lift ourselves against God; and, as it were, to countermand him.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To maintain control of, to keep under command.
